review:
Bear's Take: Uno - the classic card game that's back with a vengeance and some new tricks up its sleeve! Match cards, play action cards, and race against your friends to empty your hand. What more could you ask for?

Sip 'n' Savor: First things first, let's address the elephant in the room - or should I say, the bear? Creating a Ubisoft account just to play Uno? That's like putting a lock on your honey jar - unnecessary and a bit of a buzzkill.

Milk Mustache Moment: But let's not dwell on the negatives, shall we? At its core, Uno is still Uno - simple, chaotic, and guaranteed to start a few family feuds. It's like trying to keep your honey stash safe from a hungry bear - challenging, but oh-so-satisfying when you come out on top.

Roar Factor: As for the House Rules, are they the official Uno rules? Who knows! But does it really matter when you're having this much fun? It's like arguing over whether bears prefer salmon or honey - pointless, but entertaining nonetheless.

Bear's Bonus Honeycomb: Despite the minor hiccups, Uno is still the go-to game for a night of laughs and friendly competition. Plus, who doesn't love hitting their friends with a Draw Four when they least expect it?

Final Paw-sition: So, is Uno worth the hassle of creating a Ubisoft account? Maybe not. But once you're in, it's a wild ride of twists, turns, and plenty of laughs.

REVIEW #83
UNO
----------

For transparency, I've been holding back on doing this review because, while this PC translation of UNO has been tons of fun for me since first play, it's been riddled with bugs and issues for a handful of years (mostly pertaining to online connectivity). Since a majority of the kinks seem to be worked out in this game's current state, I feel that it's a good time to give this adaptation of UNO my recommendation.

First, it needs to be said that UNO, the original card game itself, is a fun time no matter what, but this adaption's styled interface and the way that it subtly gives the player hints on what moves are available or in the player's best interest are really well done. There's decent background music and good sound effects, TONS of gameplay options and rule variations, and there's been an addition of the MyDesign feature that lets players create their own custom decks with a staggering amount of options for details like gameplay rules and background graphics. There's also a large amount of DLC content available, and while a majority of it is only available via purchase, a lot of the DLC offered is pretty good stuff. (For additional insight on DLC specifically, I've already made a positive review for the UNO Flip pack (review #50) and a negative review for another pack (review #35).)

Ubisoft still has a lot of polishing left to do on UNO, however. I still encounter graphical glitches where cards phase through one another when other players and/or AI are drawing, and while online connectivity seems to be running solidly in its current state, I still remember having many issues in the past involving dropped connections during play (which cannot be re-established to put you back in the match that you were just in) and friends not showing up as online via Uconnect, the platform that UNO uses for online play. Therefore, I'm hesitant to say that all connection issues have been resolved, even though I haven't encountered any problems in the past handful of months.

While I'm on the subject of Uconnect, I've seen other negative reviews for this game solely mentioning the requirement of signing up with Uconnect in order to play this version of UNO. Since I willingly signed up for Steam when I purchased Half-Life 2 almost two decades ago and currently don't regret my decision, I find myself to be neutral on the requirement of a Uconnect account. Now, in the past, I will say that Uconnect certainly hasn't always proven to be a rock-solid platform, but especially as patching and fixes have been issued over time, I currently find it to be rather unintrusive and almost a non-factor as this review is concerned. In fact, nowadays, I almost forget that it's there. Still, since it does seem to be a very negative aspect for some players, I feel that it's worth mentioning for consideration before purchasing this game.

Long story short, it's UNO done pretty well for PC, and while it has its imperfections, it's perfectly playable, it looks and sounds good, and it's a heck of a lot of fun. Regardless of one's taste in games, this is unquestionably a title to consider for a purchase.

review:
Uno, the video game adaptation of the beloved card game, stands as a monument to frustration and despair‚Äîa veritable carnival of chaos where skill takes a backseat to blind luck. As a connoisseur of strategic gaming, I found myself hurling insults at the screen, cursing the fickle hand of fate that conspired against me at every turn.

The essence of Uno lies not in strategic prowess or cunning maneuvers, but in the capricious whims of chance‚Äîa fact that became painfully evident with each infuriating round. No amount of skill or foresight could shield me from the arbitrary wrath of the deck, as victory slipped through my fingers like grains of sand in an hourglass.

The people with whom I was forced to endure this ordeal proved to be no less infuriating, their ignorance matched only by their incompetence. Their reckless abandon in playing cards defied all logic and reason, turning each match into a carnival of errors and miscalculations. Were it not for the constraints of virtual space, I would have been sorely tempted to administer a lesson in basic strategy and decorum.

And yet, amidst the tumult of chaos and despair, there shone a glimmer of hope‚Äîa beacon of light in an otherwise dark and dreary landscape. The Raving Rabbids DLC, with its absurdity and irreverent charm, offered a welcome respite from the soul-crushing monotony of the base game. In their manic frenzy, the Rabbids brought a much-needed dose of levity to an otherwise joyless experience‚Äîa testament to the transformative power of whimsy in the face of adversity.

In conclusion, Uno stands as a testament to the capricious nature of fate and the folly of humanity‚Äîa game where skill counts for naught and luck reigns supreme. While its core mechanics may leave much to be desired, the Raving Rabbids DLC serves as a glimmer of hope in an otherwise bleak landscape‚Äîa reminder that even in the darkest of times, laughter can still be found amidst the chaos.

A fun port of the classic card game UNO! :D 
The bots can be surprisingly tough and it's fun to play with others online! I love the inclusion of UNO Flip! I wish they ported a few other games like UNO No Mercy but regardless this is fun game to play when you wanna play UNO but have no one to play with. 

Would've been cool if we got a more customizable rules but the ones provided suffice! I also appreciate the different skins, I really like the UNO 50th Anniversary Theme. Its cool how when playing with others it shows their themed cards. Also the 2 player mode is quite fun and a nice bonus, I am so glad this game has controller support I love playing it on my Steam Deck.

Overall this a fun game to play, 100% get it if it goes on sale!
8/10

review:
This craptastic game is from Ubisoft so it is bound to give headaches. But overall, great UNO game.

If you get the dreaded black screen of eternity after loading the game, here‚Äôs the fix:

On Nvidia Control Panel (find your way thru AMD or Intel cards software), once you run the game and have to shut it down (due to the black screen) via Steam button or Task Manager, click on Manage 3D settings > Program Settings (instead of Global) > ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù button > select uno.exe to manually add it > Select the preferred graphics processor > (select your main card instead of auto) > Specify the settings for this program > scroll down to the end and find Vertical Sync > Select ON instead of default ‚ÄúFAST‚Äù > Fixed!

Fast VSync seems to be the culprit of this issue and it comes as default at least on Nvidia cards, just switch on regular ON and that‚Äôs all. You might have different paths to this option depending on which card/software you have. Enjoy!

I'm totally disappointed at Ubisoft for destroying one of the best card games that I really enjoyed to play. Last updates brought more desyncs, connection issues and insane delays per move from no matter which player, there's always a chance on that when the other player is about to make it's move - he'll be desynced with you and you're forced to wait 10-20 minutes til the game will finally decide to react / change the host so you can continue what is very annoying. When you play only against AI - the game works fine, but when at least one player joins to your lobby / you join to someone's lobby - the game starts lagging between you and the other players what makes the game unplayable and no fun at all.

Pros:
None

Cons:
-A lot of paid DLC'S
-The game is unplayable after the last patches because the game is so laggy as hell and Ubisoft asks me to wait over 10-20 minutes til desynced player will leave the game or when the game will finally decide to try sync you again with the other players what is total disappointment
-Lack of savedata sync - what caused lost all of my progress in-game from old days
-The game is still badly optimized for some users due to possible black screen issues or problems with loading the game
-Ubisoft Connect launcher is required in order to play UNO on steam - I hate this
-Another cash-grab game made by Ubisoft in order to grab money from users and ignore every request that's related with fixing the game
-Some achievements in-game needs more explaination / proper description because they're either bugged or badly explained for a player
-No steam achievements for this game
-I think Ubisoft changed their servers to Epic Games Online Services since the game is so unstable and unplayable to everyone - big thumb down for you for this, Ubisoft >:(

Rating: 1.5/10

The game is no longer fun and playable to most of players (including me) because of Ubisoft worst decisions about releasing unstable updates and changing servers that are unstable and only causes more problems than use. Ubisoft destroyed one of the best games that I really like to play, but now sadly I must say goodbye with UNO because of Ubisoft that decided to wreck this game completely on purpose. >:(

review:
As a longtime fan of the classic card game, I was excited to try out the UNO video game, but unfortunately, my expectations were not met. While the concept of bringing UNO into the digital realm holds promise, the execution falls flat in several key areas.

First and foremost, the user interface is clunky and unintuitive, making it difficult to navigate through menus and customize game settings. 

Furthermore, the online multiplayer experience is marred by connectivity issues and lag, resulting in a choppy and unreliable gameplay experience. Matches frequently suffer from abrupt disconnects, disrupting the flow of gameplay and leaving players feeling frustrated and unsatisfied. i personally cannot even play the game due to the game crashing every time i try to play a game with my friends.

Additionally, the lack of variety in game modes and customization options is disappointing. With only a handful of basic game modes available, the replay value quickly diminishes, leaving players craving more depth and variety.

On top of these shortcomings, the graphics and sound design are lackluster, failing to capture the charm and excitement of the physical card game. The visuals are bland and uninspired, and the sound effects are repetitive and grating, further detracting from the overall enjoyment.

In summary, the UNO video game fails to capture the magic of the classic card game, offering a lackluster and underwhelming experience marred by technical issues and poor design choices. Until significant improvements are made to address these shortcomings, I cannot recommend this digital adaptation to fans of the original UNO game.

review:
I was in the shower washing suds off my girthy chest when suddenly, I heard someone shouting. I immediately drew back the shower curtains and I leaped out, like a frog escaping a pit of boiling, frothing water. Who could be shouting so late, against the indomitable silence of the night? It sounded like it came from my bedroom, where I thought nobody else had entered for years. Something was wrong.
Galvanised to action, I broke down the door and infiltrated my room. I heard the shout again. Only this time, it was clearer, and I understood everything. Cries of "UNO!" ruptured my computer speakers. And I was happy.

Ladies and gentlemen, UNO is not a game. UNO is an experience.
UNO is life, yet it is also death. It is the light at the end of the tunnel, yet it is also the darkness. It is the applause at the end of the play, but also the cold rejection of a beautiful woman.
Comrades, those of you reading these reviews to determine whether your hard-earned money should be spent on UNO, you have two simple choices; to buy or not to buy. This is the ultimate test of a man's values - do you believe that the money you have worked hard to earn is equivalent to the potential experience of UNO for Windows?
Some may be hesitant. But to quote poet Robert Frost, "In three words, I can sum up everything I've learned about life: it goes on". Whether you buy UNO or not, the worst case scenario is not life-destroying. Life will go on if you spend money on UNO and it is not for you. Yet there is so much that awaits you if you buy UNO and, like millions of others, you find yourself utterly absorbed in the magic of UNO.

I would go further and argue that everyone reading this should buy UNO for Windows. At the time of writing, 30% of reviews are negative. Yet do not be deterred; by finding yourself here, you have demonstrated an interest in this game, and the only way to truly know whether you like a game or not is to play it yourself. Reviews are useful to a point, but in the words of Frank Sinatra, do not be "one who kneels" to popular opinion. Do not pretend for an instant that any review here will define your experience of UNO. There will be some who despise it, and others who are utterly enraptured by it. You must find where on this colourful spectrum you fall, and only you can decide that.

I hope that every potential player reading this searches deep into the labyrinths of their heart and soul and finds the answer.

I love Uno, I enjoy having a digital option so I can play with my friends long-distance... but [i]this[/i] is just not a good recreation. The game itself can be buggy in all sorts of ways, joining public lobbies just completely suck. Why is there no option of what lobby you join ? There are some rules that I don't like to play with or play without, is it really that hard to just add options ?? I don't want to have to keep joining and leaving the same lobby five times just to try and find a different lobby.
And why is there not an option to play with bots ? My two friends aren't always around to play when I want to play and when the only lobby it's shoving me in isn't to my liking, I just end up not playing at all. Even inside a public match, if everyone leaves and all there is are bots, once the game ends that's it. You have to leave the lobby now because you're all by your stupid lonesome self.
It feels like Ubisoft [i]doesn't[/i] want you to play their game...

Being forced to make an Ubisoft account just to play is also stupid. You can't even chose your own icon because the company doesn't know how to moderate images apparently.
This company is one of those that would rather take away something than actually fix it so just keep that in mind going in.

[h3]What I want to see:[/h3]
-Option to pick the public lobby you join
-Online singleplayer, for when you have no friends but still wanna play Uno and have the option of people joining your game
-Better optimisation, the game runs badly and loads soooooo slowly

I'm sure I'll think of more later.
